oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Magnolia cotton gin
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: An advertisement that shows a cotton gin that is a feeder and condenser. The caption reads the Gullett Improved Light Draft Magnolia Cotton Gin, Feeder and Condenser.

The cotton gin is a device for removing the seeds from cotton fiber. In 1794, Eli Whitney developed a cotton gin that cleaned short-staple cotton. With this device, fifty pounds of cleaned cotton could be produced in a day. As a result, cotton production grew each decade after 1800. By the 1850s, America was growing three-quarters of the world's supply of cotton, most of it shipped to England or New England where it was manufactured into cloth.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Cotton gins and ginning; Cotton; Cotton gins and ginning -- Tennessee -- Chattanooga
